Targeted whole genome amplification and next-generation sequencing (NGS) techniques have 43 been used in sequencing SARS-CoV-2 genomes (8, 10, 13) . In contrast to the high throughput 44 capacity of NGS, using a conventional multiplexing reverse transcription and polymerase chain 45 reaction (RT-PCR) procedures to amplify the large 30 Kb viral genomic RNA of SARS-CoV-2 46 is tedious, technically challenging, and has variable contamination risks. A rapid and streamlined 47 approach with fewer manual steps to obtain whole genome amplicons suitable for NGS is 48 desired.

In this study, we utilize an integrated microfluidic nucleic acid amplification system (14), custom 50 primer design, and a one-step RT-PCR program to amplify whole SARS-CoV-2 genomes. After 51 NGS of the amplicons, an in-house developed bioinformatics pipeline is used to rapidly obtain 52 genome sequences with graphic summaries for data and results visualization. The NGS libraries were prepared using Illumina DNA Flex Library kit (Illumina, CA, USA).
DNA was fragmentized by tagmentation for 15 mins followed by indexing and library 91 amplification, with 6 cycles used for 25 ng of amplicon or 12 cycles used for 1-9 ng of amplicon.

The first sequence was made publicly available 170 immediately with a massive number of sequences subsequently generated and shared, which has 171 greatly facilitated research and development (23-25). All the efforts in developing, improving, 172 and sharing materials and/or methods has played an essential role in sequence-based 173 investigations. All the known sequencing protocols use conventional PCR apparatuses with 174 differences in design and selection of primers and reaction parameters. In this study, we applied 175 one-step RT-PCR protocol on a microfluidic platform (14) to establish a convenient workflow 176 with throughput, speed, simplicity, consistency, and yield suitable for COVID-19 genome 177 sequencing.
